head.title: Aratus Latinus in a hotchpotch of texts

supportDesc.collation: Based on the description made by L. J. Engels "composite (17 codicilli), gatherings (mostly quaternions) often incomplete and showing various prickings and quire signatures (regularly pared off)". These 17 codicilli should include: ff. 1-21, ff. 22-35, ff. 36-57, ff. 58-65, ff. 66-73, ff. 79-92, ff. 93-98, ff. 99-106, ff. 107-22, ff. 123-37, ff. 138-56, ff. 157-64, ff. 165-72, ff. 179-86, ff. 187-200, ff. 201-23. ff. 224-31.

handDesc.handNote: Written from many hands. In the gathering of Aratus Latinus at least three hands changing on fols. 103vb, 104ra and 104va.

origin.p: Accoring to Horst Schlechte (1934) and Karl Manitius (1955) the manuscript was written at St. Eucharius-Matthias in Trier about the middle or even at the end of the 12th c.

provenance.p: Van de Vyver recognised the hand of Nicholas of Cues on the margins (see bibliography). Hence the manuscript was probably at the St. Nikolaus-Hospital (Cusanusstift) in the 15th c. Between 1657 and 1778 it was in the possession of the Bollandists in Antwerp. Afterwards it was transfered in the Bibliothèque de Bourgogne. In the years 1794-1815 was at the Bibliothèque National in Paris before it was returned to Belgium.

listBibl.head: Selected bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Grocock, C. W. and E. Siberry ed. The Historia Vie Hierosolimitane of Gilo of Paris. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1997, p. xl.
Sedulius Scottus, Sedulii Scotti Carmina, ed. Jean Meyers. (Corpus Christianorum, Continuatio Mediaeualis, 117.) Turnhout: Brepols, 1991.
Vansteenberghe, Edmond. Le cardinal Nicolas de Cues: (1401 - 1464); l’action - la pensée. Geneve: Slatkine reprints, 1974, p. 22.
Paniagua, D. "El Glossarium Bruxellense (Bruxelles, Bibl. Roy. 10615-10729, ff. 95v-96r). Edición y comentario glosográfico," Voces 17 (2006): 41-108.
Calcoen, R. Inventaire des manuscrits scientifiques de la Bibliothèque Royale Albert Ier, t. III, Bruxelles: Centre National d'histoire des sciences, 1975, p. 37.

Davis, R. H., L. J. Engels et al."The Carmen de Hestingae Proleio: a discussion," in R. Allen Brown ed. Proceedings of the Battle Conference on Anglo-Norman Studies II, Suffolk: Boydell Press, 1980, pp. 1-20.
Manitius, M. "Zur poetischen Literatur aus bruxell. 10615-729," Neues Archiv 39 (1914): 155-75.
Manitius, K. "Eine Gruppe von Handschriften des 12. Jahrhunderts aus dem Trierer Kloster St. Eucharius-matthias," Forschungen und Fortschritte 29 (1955): 317-19.
de Rijk, L. M. "On the Curriculum of the Arts f the Trivium at St. gall from c. 850-c. 1000," Vivarium 1 (1963): 35-86.
Schlechte, H. Erzbischof Bruno von Trier. Ein Beitrag zur Geschichte der geistigen Strömungen im Investiturstreit. Leipzig: Vogel, 1934 (esp. pp. 71-78).

Olsen, M. L'étude des auteurs classiques latins aux xie et xiie siècles, IV. 2, p. 366. gives this manuscript as an example that not every composite manuscript was assembled becaue there its texts are related. According to Olsen it coms from Trèves s.xii2: a large volume of 231 ff. divided in 21 elements, 27,5 x 19 cm two colums 70 lines, "on s'est proposé apparemment de créer un vaste corpus de tout les textes qu'on pu trouver dans les bibliothèques de la région
Van de Vyver, E. 'Marginalia van Nicolaus van Cusa in Bata-codex 271 en andere codices van de Koninklijke Bibliotheek te Brussel', Tijdschrift voor Philosophie, 18 (1956), p. 439-456.

msItem.title: De natura
msItem.explicit: quod uero immensum est bonitate pater est uirtute conditor.
msItem.bibl: Ed. P. Piper Die Schriften Notkers I, 1882, S. XLIX-L

msItem.explicit: (non illa in aliis et de aliis).
msItem.note: Identified by A. Kaffarnik (Querela magistri Treverensis, p. 328) as Dicta V (Quomodo quidquid sit) and VI (Quid sit substantia) from Dicta Candidi de imagine Dei of Candidus from Fulda. These are followed by three lines of unidentified addition: Omnis res significat substantiam aut acidens si dico albus aut niger qualitatem significo. These lines are transcribed by Piper.
msItem.bibl: Ed. P. Piper Die Schriften Notkers I, 1882, S. L-LI.

msItem.incipit: Speciales francorum protectores sunt dyonisius martyr
Hic est stellarum ordo utrorumque circulorum
msItem.note: with section titles in the margin or in line for each zodiacal sign.

msItem.incipit: A ioue incipimus quem numquam uiri relinquimus
msItem.note: With rubrics for sections devoted to some of the constellations (Helice arctvrvs maior, De dracone, De eo qui in geniculo est etc.) with the exception for sections from Leo to Cassiopeia. Left blank spaces in the middle of the lines on a few occasions. Like Paris, BnF MS lat. 7887 has the text corresponding to vv. 909-1002 after the section corresponding to vv. 1068-1074, here written by a different hand.
AL, I Arati ea quae videntur:
msItem.incipit: Ostensionem quoque de quibus uidentur oportet fieri
msItem.note: Some corrections in the names of constellations, as well as insertion in the margin in f. 104rb of a missed out phrase simulque piscis cauda cancri pes scorpioni pars.
Al, II Eratosthenis de circa exornatione:
msItem.incipit: Eratostenes de circa exornatione stellarum ethumologia de quibus uidentur haec autem sunt ad aquilonem septentrio maior
msItem.explicit: pisces cetus incolo in manu utraque semisphera aquilo aries thaurus gemini.

msItem.incipit: quibus arathi uidentur quaedam sunt secundum celi stellatum
Habet autem pondere totum medio terre
Aratus genus patris quidem est athinodori
msItem.explicit: autem illum et illum et super
